title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #860: Prime Covering Intervals**

Estimate h(n), the minimum interval length such that any interval of that length contains distinct multiples of the first π(n) primes.

**Status: OPEN** (bounds known, exact asymptotics unknown)

**Known:** (3-o(1))n < h(n) ≪ n^(3/2)/(log n)^(1/2)

title: PrimeCovering
content:
**Prime Covering Assignment:** A function assigning to each of the first k primes a distinct multiple from an interval.

Requirements:
- All assignments in the interval (m, m+L]
- All assignments distinct
- pᵢ divides the i-th assignment

title: AdmitsCovering
content:
**Admissible Interval:** An interval (m, m+L] admits a prime covering for k primes if such an assignment exists.

The function h(n) is the minimum L making all intervals admissible.

title: h
content:
**The Function h(n):** The minimum interval length L such that EVERY interval (m, m+L] admits a covering for the first π(n) primes.

This is the central object of study: h(n) = min{L : ∀m, AdmitsCovering m L π(n)}.

title: h_universal
content:
**Universality of h(n):** Every interval of length h(n) admits a covering.

This is the defining property: h(n) is large enough to work for ALL starting points m.

title: erdos_selfridge_lower_bound
content:
**Erdős-Selfridge Lower Bound:** h(n) > (3-o(1))n.

The interval must be at least about 3n long. This is a linear lower bound, showing h(n) grows at least linearly with n.

title: ruzsa_growth
content:
**Ruzsa's Result:** h(n)/n → ∞ as n → ∞.

The growth is superlinear! The ratio h(n)/n is unbounded, so h(n) grows faster than any linear function cn.

title: erdos_pomerance_upper_bound
content:
**Erdős-Pomerance Upper Bound:** h(n) ≪ n^(3/2)/(log n)^(1/2).

An explicit upper bound that is subquadratic. This means h(n) = o(n²), so intervals of length n² are more than sufficient.

title: linear_lower_bound
content:
**Linear Lower Bound Theorem:** h(n) ≥ cn for some constant c > 0.

Derived from Erdős-Selfridge: we can take c close to 3 for large n.

title: subquadratic_upper_bound
content:
**Subquadratic Growth:** h(n) = o(n²).

The function h(n) is asymptotically smaller than n². This follows from the Erdős-Pomerance bound.

title: The Gap
content:
**The Open Problem:** We know n·ω(n) ≤ h(n) ≤ n^(3/2-ε) for some slowly growing ω(n).

What is the exact growth rate? Is h(n) = Θ(n^α) for some 1 < α < 3/2?

title: Bipartite Matching
content:
**Graph-Theoretic View:** h(n) is the least L such that for all m, the bipartite graph with primes on one side and interval elements on the other (with edges for divisibility) has a perfect matching on the prime side.

Hall's theorem characterizes when such matchings exist.

title: Hall's Condition
content:
**Hall's Marriage Theorem:** A matching exists iff for every subset S of primes, |N(S)| ≥ |S| where N(S) is the set of multiples in the interval.

This condition must hold for all intervals and all prime subsets.

title: erdos_860
content:
**Erdős Problem #860: OPEN**

Main theorem stating the known results:
1. Superlinear growth: h(n)/n → ∞ (Ruzsa)
2. Polynomial upper bound: h(n) ≪ n^(3/2)/(log n)^(1/2)

The exact asymptotic behavior remains unknown.
